title: Analysis of brain region-specific mRNA synthesis and stability by utilizing adult mouse brain slice culture
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of acute mouse brain slices from adult mice
Timing: 1–2 h per mouse
This section describes how to prepare mouse brain slices before applying chemical agents to the cultures. In this protocol, two mice (one WT and the other ataxin-1 KO) are used to prepare brain slices.
Note: The overall goal of this procedure is to prepare healthy brain slices from mature adult mice that are suitable for pharmacology and electrophysiology experiments. This brain slice preparation, from mice of virtually of any age, allows researchers to explore changes in gene expression up to 2 days after application of drugs/chemicals in the slice culture.
Critical: Good handling and quick transition between the steps of the procedure is desired. Individual slices should reach their new culture dish quickly without much time outside of the oxygenated aCSF. Once the slices are in their temporal incubation chambers the next mouse may be started at step 8 allowing for the sectioning of multiple mouse brains for a single experiment. Entire time from anaesthetizing a mouse for decapitation (step 8) to transfer for brain slice to temporal dish (step 14) may be completely within 30 min. Two mouse brains can be sliced and processed in a single experiment without compromising culture quality.
Place 500 mL aCSF in −20°C freezer and chill until ice-cold (< 4°C). Avoid over-freezing as this can change osmolarity of the solution.
Prepare all sterile instruments for surgery and dissection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1610-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Preparation of brain slices from adult mice
(A) Photograph of microtome (left), slice culture dishes (middle), and surgery equipment (right). One big culture dish is for temporal incubation and two small dishes are for incubation up to 2 days.
(B) Stone cylinder producing air bubbles in aCSF solution.

(C) 5-ports manifolds with female luer locks controlling oxygenation level in the culture.
(D) Folded filter paper that keep brain slices from different mice separate.
(E) Brain slice sectioning within ice-cold chamber. ∗, bubbling blue tube to oxygenate in the chamber.
(F) Coronally sectioned brain slices.
Place a large glass or plastic Petri dish (150 mm-diameter) on ice, place the round filter paper on the bottom.
Set a small micro-bubbler oxygen diffuser connected to a gas tank via flexible tubing and 5-ports manifold (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A and 1C).
Add 150 mL of ice-cold aCSF. Oxygenate the aCSF solution with 95% O2/5% CO2 gas.
This Petri dish is used for brain dissection only.
Install one additional glass or plastic Petri dish (150 mm-diameter) as described in step 3. This large Petri dish is used for temporal incubation of brain slices (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Note: Oxygenation level in the culture dish is persistently controlled by 5-ports manifold with female luer locks to avoid excessive bubbling (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
In the dish prepared in step 4, put a round filter paper that is folded to make a separation barrier in the middle, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D. This folded-barrier is useful to separate brain slices from WT to those from ataxin-1 KO mice.
Prepare two additional plastic Petri dishes (100 mm-diameter) as described in steps 4–5 for a long-term slice incubation.
Dilute 37.5 μL stock Act-D solution in 75 mL aCSF solution to make 10 μM final concentration.
Dilute 37.5 μL DMSO solution in 75 mL aCSF solution to make vehicle control.
In each Petri dish, pour either the vehicle (DMSO) or Act-D CSF solution.
Cover Petri dishes with corresponding plastic lids. Cover the entire culture dishes with dark fabric and/or aluminum foil to prevent light exposure and keep them at room temperature (20°C–22°C).

Note: The plastic lids should have a small open space at the edge to allow plastic tubing that supplies oxygen to the culture to pass though.
Set a vibratome (Leica VT-1000S) to cut brain at 375–400 μm thickness (375 μm for older, 400 μm for younger mice).
Use the cutting brain speed at ∼ 0.25 mm/s and blade sectioning (vibration) frequency ∼ 90 Hz.
Blade return stroke is performed at constant speed of 5 mm/s.
Fill the slicing chamber of the vibratome with ice-cold aCSF solution and oxygenate it carefully (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E).
Fill the tray surrounding the slicing chamber with a slurry of ice and water to keep it cool.
Place a razor blade in the blade holder.
Anaesthetize one adult WT mouse with isoflurane, decapitate and remove the brain rapidly.
Place the brain in the dissection Petri dish on ice that contains oxygenated ice-cold aCSF. For coronal sectioning, cut off the cerebellum and a small prefrontal cortex part (∼ 3 mm) with a razor blade.
Attach the brain onto the specimen disc of vibratome with fast adhesive glue at cerebellum-cut side (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E and 1F). Orient dorsal side to face the razor blade.
Note: A piece of agar fixed with adhesive glue on the specimen disc and placed on the ventral-side of brain provides additional support during slice cutting (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F). It is recommended that the agar block is 1–2 mm taller than the dissected brain to provide support.
Define the start and stop positions of the slicing, and slice down the brain with the vibratome. Usually, one brain produces 8–12 coronally sectioned 375–400 μm-thick slices (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
Upon completion of the sectioning, gently transfer individual brain slices with wide-mouthed transfer pipet to the temporal incubation dish filled with oxygenated prechilled aCSF (prepared at step 4).

In the temporal incubation dish, arrange the brain slices on one side of the peak-folded filter paper in a sequence from anterior to posterior direction (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1610-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Brain slice culture chemical agent treatment and incubation
(A) Slices arranged from anterior to posterior side of a mouse brain. Size bar = 1 cm.
(B) WT and ataxin-1 KO brain slices are treated with vehicle control (left) or chemical agent (e.g., Act-D; right) and incubated with oxygenation.
To obtain brain slices from ataxin-1 KO mouse, repeat steps 9–14. Ice-cold aCSF in the vibratome should be changed. When transferring the ataxin-1 KO slices to temporal incubation dishes, place them on the other side on the filter paper (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Note: One or two brain slices from WT and ataxin-1 KO mice are used to measure initial electrophysiological activity in hippocampal CA1 before the start of slice culture (steps 21–28). Use the remaining aCSF for perfusion solution.
Brain slice culture to analyze mRNA stability: Actinomycin D treatment
Timing: 0.5–1 h for Act-D treatment; 48 h for culture incubation
This section describes how to apply aCSF solution containing either Act-D or vehicle to brain slices and maintain the treated slice cultures up to 2 days.
Critical: To minimize variation in culture condition, brain slices from two mice (i.e., WT and ataxin-1 KO) to be compared are maintained side-by-side throughout the incubation within same culture dishes.
For each brain slices kept in temporal dish (prepared at steps 14 and 15), from anterior to posterior, assign numbers (e.g., WT1, WT2, …, KO1, KO2, …).
Transfer brain slices of WT mice to incubation culture dishes.
Transfer the odd-numbered brain slices on to the left side of filter paper barrier (peak) in the long-term slice incubation culture dish that contains vehicle control.

Transfer the remaining even-numbered brain slices on to the left side of filter paper in the other long-term slice incubation culture dish that contains Act-D (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Note: The two sets of coronally-sectioned brain slices from one mouse, divided half by this way (even- or odd-numbered; 4–6 slices each), are very comparable to each other in their structural composition. This approach reduces experimental variations that are generated from different mice used in examining the effects of pharmacological agents (vehicle vs. Act-D) on cultured brain slices.
Transfer brain slices of ataxin-1 KO mice to incubation culture dishes.
Transfer the odd-numbered brain slices on to the right side of filter paper barrier (peak) in the long-term slice incubation culture dish that contain vehicle control.
Transfer the remaining even-numbered brain slices on to the right side of filter paper in the other long-term slice incubation culture dish that contains Act-D.
Note: Brain slices from WT and ataxin-1 KO mice should not be mixed or confused. The separation of the two brain slice sets within a same culture dish can be maintained by a filter paper that has a folded barrier (peak) in the middle and by stones that hold down the filter paper (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). Substantial physical impact on the dish or sudden move of the dish, which can cause detachment of the brain slices from filter papers and floating and mixing of the slices in the dish, should be avoided.
Cover the dishes with corresponding plastic lids to avoid excess evaporation. Cover the entire culture dishes with dark fabric and/or aluminum foil to block light as Act-D is sensitive to light. The slice cultures are incubated at room temperature (20°C–22°C).

Critical: Maintaining continued oxygenation of the slice cultures throughout incubation period is essential. Make sure 95% O2/5% CO2 tank has plenty of gas for the entire incubation period.
24 h after the start of incubation, replace 75% of the culture media with fresh prepared room temperature aCSF containing either vehicle or Act-D.
To avoid the floating and mixing of brain slices within culture dish, carefully and slowly take out the used media and add the new media with a Pasteur pipet from the edge of culture dish.
Slice culture is incubated for 24 or 48 h before harvesting them for electrophysiological recordings or total RNA isolation.
Electrophysiological setup and recordings
Timing: 1–2 h per mouse
This section describes electrophysiological extracellular field recordings in individual slices (Dzhala et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]), before and after the slice culture. One of the purposes of this procedure is to validate the neuronal action potential activity and suitability of the brain slices for ex vivo pharmacological experiments.
Prepare setup for electrophysiological recordings.
Use a flexible tubing to connect a leveling laboratory bottle (e.g., 1,000 mL Duran Aspirator bottle) outlet with a 1-way polycarbonate on/off stop valve for solution flow.
Fill up DURAN Aspirator (leveling) bottle with 500 mL aCSF. Continuously oxygenate the aCSF solution with 95% O2/5% CO2 gas.
Use a flexible tubing to connect the leveling bottle with a single in-line solution heater (e.g., SF-27B, SF-28) and recording submersion-type chamber.
Setup solution flow by gravity, flow rate control and temperature control at 32°C.
For electrophysiological recordings, transfer individual slice to a conventional submersion-type chamber (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A and 3B) and continuously superfuse with oxygenated aCSF at 32°C at a rate of 2 mL/min. Stabilize tissue brain slice using appropriate U-shape slice anchor made by platinum bar.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1610-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Electrophysiological recording and brain slice dissection

(A) Settings for electrophysiological recording of brain slices in vitro superfused with oxygenated aCSF.
(B) Extracellular field potential recordings are performed in CA1 pyramidal cell layer using tungsten microelectrodes. Size bar = 0.5 cm.
(C) Dissected cortex and hippocampus from brain slice.
Use commercial or custom-made tungsten microelectrodes for extracellular field potential recordings of multiple-unit activity (MUA) and population field potential activity.
Note: Use of microelectrodes made from coated tungsten wire 50 μm in diameter enables simultaneous recordings of multiple-unit activity (MUA, 400 Hz high-pass filter) and population field activity (EEG band, 1–100 Hz) from tens to hundreds of neurons near each electrode. Root-mean-square noise level with an electrode placed in the perfusion solution is typically 4–5 μV, whereas the amplitude of action potentials recorded from the stratum pyramidale ranges from this noise level up to 200 μV.
Attach the electrodes to the electrode holders of the amplifier head-stages and turn into position (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Use fine micromanipulators to position the recording electrodes to the area of interest within the brain slice (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Once electrode is in contact with healthy pyramidal cell layer, monitor extracellular field potential activity using computer-controlled software.
Perform extracellular field potential recordings of MUA using computer-controlled software (pCLAMP version 10.3 or higher, Molecular Devices) and data acquisition (analog-to-digital converter Digidata 1440, Molecular Devices).
Perform data analysis and statistical comparison of the data. Optional, use Mini Analysis Program (Synaptosoft), and Origin (OriginLab Corporation) programs for data analysis. Determine the amplitude and frequency of MUA from high-pass filtered (400 Hz) raw data with a spike detection algorithm (Mini Analysis Program) and verify visually (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1610-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Spontaneous neuronal activity of CA1 and CA3 cells in incubated slices

(A and B) Simultaneous extracellular field potential records of multiple unit activity in the CA1 and CA3 areas in control (A) and Actinomycin D-treated (B) brain slices 48 h after incubation. Wide-band recordings at 0.1–10 kHz.
(C and D) Histograms representing spike amplitude distribution (C) and inter-event interval (D) in control and Actinomycin D-treated slices.
Dissection of brain regions after slice incubation
Timing: 1–2 h per mouse
This section describes how to dissect out individual brain regions (e.g., cortex) after slice incubation.
Prepare forceps and dissection microscope.
Transfer cultured brain slices to Petri dishes that are filled with fresh ice-cold aCSF solution. During the slice transfer and dissection, aCSF does not need to be oxygenated.
To avoid mixing the slices from different mice, transfer WT and ataxin-1 KO slices to separate dishes.
Transfer vehicle- and Act-D treated slices to different dishes. So, the brain slices from two incubation dishes are now divided into four for dissection.
Keep the dishes containing the brain slice on ice during the dissection.
Using forceps, cut out cortex from brain slices under dissection microscope (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Note: Here, the cortex is dissected out for further mRNA analysis as it exhibits, among several brain regions, the most distinct difference in steady-state Bace1 mRNA level between WT and ataxin-1 KO mice. Other brain regions (e.g., hippocampus or striatum) can be dissected if needed.
Remove aCSF droplets from dissected cortex with Kimwipe tissue paper.
Put cortex pieces into 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes and keep on dry ice to freeze.
Repeat step from steps 31 to 33 until all brain slices are dissected.
Pause point: Dissected brain slice piece samples (e.g., cortex) can be stored at −80°C until use.
Isolation of total RNA
Timing: 4–6 h for 20 brain slices

This section describes how to isolate total RNA with Trizol reagent from mouse brain slice pieces (e.g., cortex) for subsequent RT-qPCR analysis. Total RNA can be isolated by other methods, such as utilizing RNeasy Kits (QIAGEN).
Add 1 mL ice-cold Trizol reagent into 1 mL-size Dounce homogenizer.
Put pieces of cortex from one brain slice into the Trizol reagent.
Grind the tissue pieces with a tight pestle for 20 strokes up and down with twist.
Follow Trizol reagent manufacturer’s instruction to isolate total RNA (Invitrogen, www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/brands/product-brand/trizol.html[href=http://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/brands/product-brand/trizol.html]). DNase treatment is not needed. Briefly,
Incubate for 5 min to allow complete dissociation of the tissue lysates.
Add 0.2 mL chloroform and vortex for 30 s.
Incubate for 5 min at room temperature and centrifuge for 10 min at 13,000 × g at 4°C.
Transfer the upper clear aqueous phase (400 μL) that contains RNA to a new tube.
Add equal volume (400 μL) of isopropanol to the aqueous phase and vortex for 10 s.
Incubate for 30 min on ice and centrifuge for 10 min at 13,000 × g at 4°C.
Note: Incubation on ice for longer time helps the precipitation of the relatively small amount of RNA from brain slice pieces. After centrifugation, total RNA precipitate forms a white pellet at the bottom of the tube.
Carefully discard the supernatant without disturbing the pellet and add 1 mL 75% ethanol to the remaining pellet.
Rinse the pellet with the 75% ethanol solution by inverting the tube several times.
Centrifuge for 5 min at 13,000 × g at 4°C and carefully discard the supernatant.
Air-dry RNA pellet on 70°C heat block until no remaining solution is visible in the tube.

Note: Avoid over-drying (> 3 min) the RNA pellet. Over-drying may impede the resuspension of RNA pellet in nuclease-free water in the subsequent step. It may also cause poor RNA quality.
Resuspend RNA pellet (invisible) with 15 μL nuclease-free water.
Pause point: Isolated RNA samples can be stored at −80°C until use.
RNA integrity can be assessed by the detection of distinct 28S and 18S rRNA bands in 1% agarose gel running.
Note: The weight of all cortical piece from one coronally sectioned brain slice is ∼10 mg. Total RNA amount isolated from the cortical piece is ∼4–8 μg.
RT-qPCR analysis of Bace1 mRNA
Timing: 4–6 h for 20 RNA samples
Dilute each RNA samples to 250 ng/μL concentration in nuclease-free distilled water.
Set up reverse transcription (RT) reaction in a 96-well PCR plate as indicated in the table below.
To run RT reaction for multiple RNA samples, make a master mix that includes all reagents except RNA.
For RT reaction, iScript Advanced cDNA Synthesis Kits is used (refer to “key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]”).
To assess any genomic DNA or PCR product contamination, control RT reaction (no RT) that does not contain reverse transcriptase should be included.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_5.csv
Run the RT reaction for 20 min at 46°C followed by 10°C holding in a PCR machine (CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR Detection System).
Transfer all the RT products into new Eppendorf tubes.
Pause point: RT product samples can be stored at −80°C until use.
For each RT product, set up Bace1 cDNA qPCR reaction in a 96-well PCR plate as indicated in table below.
To run qPCR reaction for multiple RT products, make a master mix that includes all reagents except RT products.
The PCR reactions should be performed in duplicate or triplicate.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_6.csv

Within same 96-well PCR plate, set up Gapdh cDNA qPCR reactions as described for Bace1 cDNA qPCR (step 44). Gapdh expression level is used as control to calculate ΔCt (threshold cycle) values.
Note: In this protocol, qPCR reactions for Bace1 and Gapdh are run in separate PCR reaction wells. However, both qPCR reactions for one RT product can be run within same well by adding 1 μl each of TaqMan assay solution that includes forward and reverse PCR primers of corresponding genes and fluorescent probes. For this multiplex qPCR reaction, the amount of nuclease-free water is reduced from 7 to 6 μl for each qPCR reaction.
Run qPCR reaction as indicated in table below.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_7.csv
Determine Ct values for Bace1 and Gapdh, based on the earliest cycles of exponential phase of the PCR reactions. Get an average of Ct value for each target gene (e.g., Bace1) from duplicate or triplicate PCR reactions.
Calculate ΔCt value of each target mRNA. For example, ΔCt(Bace1) = Ct(Bace1) – Ct(Gapdh). Calculate the average of ΔCt values for each treatment group (e.g., 0 h_WT). Details of qPCR result analysis can also be found at https://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/life-science/pcr/real-time-pcr/real-time-pcr-learning-center.html[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/life-science/pcr/real-time-pcr/real-time-pcr-learning-center.html].
Calculate ΔΔCt values of each sample. ΔΔCt value is calculated based on the control experimental group (e.g., 0 h_WT). For example, ΔΔCt (Bace1_24 h_KO_VH) = average of ΔCt (0 h_WT) – ΔCt (Bace1_24 h_KO_VH).
Calculate 100 × 2ΔΔCt value of each sample and analyze the results.
Average of 100 × 2ΔΔCt (0 h_WT) will be assign as 100 as control group (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1610-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. RT-qPCR analysis of brain slices to assess the stability and transcription of Bace1 mRNA

(A) Actinomycin D or vehicle (DMSO) was treated for 24 and 48 h in acute brain slice cultures. In bar, number of brain slice is analyzed. Data are pooled from 3 mice per each genotype. Data are represented as mean ± SEM. ∗∗p < 0.01, ∗∗∗p < 0.001, t test.
(B) Ratio of Bace1 mRNA levels in ataxin-1 KO and WT brain slices. n.s., not significant.
(C) Example of real-time qPCR amplification curves of steady-state (total) and nascent Bace1 mRNA (green). Gapdh mRNA (blue) levels were measured as control. For the analysis of nascent mRNA, brain slices were incubated for 3 h in aCSF containing 5-ethynyl uridine.
The relative amount of Bace1 mRNA in each sample will be 100 × 2ΔΔCt. For example, the relative amount of Bace1 mRNA in 24 h_KO_VH sample will be 100 × 2ΔΔCt (24 h_KO_VH).
Analyze 100 × 2ΔΔCt values of each treatment group at each time point (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
Analyze ratios of Bace1 mRNA levels between ataxin-1 KO and WT in vehicle or Act-D treatment group at each time point (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Brain slice culture to analyze mRNA synthesis: 5 ethynyl uridine (5EU) treatment
Timing: 1 day
This section describes how to apply aCSF solution containing either 5EU or vehicle to brain slices to measure newly synthesized mRNA. For the 5EU treatment and subsequent nascent mRNA isolation (Steps from 51 to 69), we utilized Click-iT Nascent RNA Capture Kit (Refer to “key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]”).
Critical: To minimize variation in culture conditions (e.g., exposure to 5EU), brain slices from two mice (i.e., WT and ataxin-1 KO) to be compared are maintained side-by-side within same culture dishes throughout the incubation.

Prepare 5-ethynyl uridine (5EU) working solution by adding 50 μL of the 5EU stock solution to 50 mL aCSF for a final concentration of 0.2 mM. Prepare vehicle control solution by adding 50 μL DMSO to 50 mL aCSF for a final concentration to 0.1%.
Prepare mouse brain slices from ataxin-1 KO and WT mice as described in steps 1–15 at “preparation of acute mouse brain slices from adult mice[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.1],” except for step 6. Instead of Act-D, use 5EU solution and corresponding vehicle control solution made in step 51.
Transfer WT mouse brain slices to culture dishes as similar to what is described for Act-D treatment (“brain slice culture to analyze mRNA stability: Actinomycin D treatment[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.2]”).
Transfer odd-numbered brain slices of WT mice on to the left side of filter paper peak in one culture dish that contains vehicle control.
Transfer the remaining even-numbered brain slices on to the left side of the filter paper peak in the other culture dish that contains 5EU.
Transfer ataxin-1 KO mouse brain slices to culture dishes.
Transfer even-numbered brain slices of ataxin-1 KO mice on to the right side of filter paper peak in the culture dish that contains vehicle control.
Transfer the remaining even-numbered brain slices on to the right side of filter paper peak in the other culture dish that contains 5EU.
Cover the dishes with corresponding plastic lids to avoid excess evaporation. Cover the entire dishes with dark fabric and/or aluminum foil to block light at room temperature (20°C–22°C).
Critical: Maintaining continued oxygenation of the slice cultures throughout incubation period is essential.
Harvest brain slices at 3 and 16 h after incubation and dissect brain regions (e.g., cortex) as described in steps 29–34 at “dissection of brain regions after slice incubation[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.4].”

Note: After the incubation, one or two brain slices can be used to measure the electrophysiological activity of hippocampal CA1 neurons, as described in steps 21–28 at “electrophysiological recordings of brain slices[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.3].”
Biotinylation of 5EU containing nascent RNA
Timing: 1 day for 6 RNA samples
This section describes how to biotinylate 5EU containing nascent RNA by utilizing Click-iT reaction. We utilized Click-iT Nascent RNA Capture Kit (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]) for this procedure. Refer to manufacturer’s instruction for details (www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365[href=http://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365]).
Isolate total RNA from dissected brain slices containing 5EU (step 56) with Trizol reagent as described in steps 35–39 at “isolation of total RNA[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.5].”
Note: Total RNA concentration for Click-iT reaction should be 1 μg/μL. To achieve this concentration, put 4–6 cortex pieces of same treatment group (e.g., 16 h-WT) in 1 mL Trizol reagent when isolating total RNA and resuspend the resulting RNA pellet in 15 μL distilled nuclease-free water. Approximately 20–40 μg of total RNA could be obtained from this preparation.
Dilute the RNA into 1 μg/μL and use 10 μg RNA for one Click-iT reaction.
Prepare Click-iT reaction cocktail (50 μL per reaction) according to Table below. Add the reaction components in the order listed.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_8.csv
Incubate the Click-iT reaction mix for 30 min by gently mixing it on a laboratory vertical rotating mixer.
Precipitate the RNA with glycogen following the manufacturer’s protocol (https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365]). Briefly,
Add 1 μL of UltraPure Glycogen (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]), 50 μL of 7.5 M ammonium acetate, and 700 μL of ice-cold 100% ethanol to the click reaction. Mix the tube contents by inverting the tube several times.
Incubate the tube overnight at –70°C and centrifuge at 13,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C.
Carefully discard the supernatant without disturbing the pellet and add 1 mL 75% ethanol to the remaining pellet.

Rinse the pellet with the 75% ethanol solution by inverting the tube several times.
Centrifuge for 5 min at 13,000 × g at 4°C and carefully discard the supernatant.
Air-dry RNA pellet on 70°C heat block until no remaining solution are visible in the tube.
Note: Avoid over-drying (> 3 min) the RNA pellet.
Resuspend RNA pellet (invisible) in 50 μL distilled nuclease-free water.
Note: The RNA yield after Click-iT reaction is ∼ 80%–100% of the starting material. The resuspended RNA can be stored at −80°C until further use.
Isolation of biotinylated RNA by streptavidin magnetic beads
Timing: 2–3 h for 6 RNA samples
This section describes how to bind biotinylated nascent RNA to streptavidin magnetic beads. The binding reaction and the isolation of nascent RNA transcript are carried out with Click-iT Nascent RNA Capture Kit following manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/C10365]). Below are brief steps for one RNA sample from brain slice cultures. For more reactions, scale up the volumes accordingly.
Using a magnetic separation rack, wash 50 μL streptavidin-conjugated bead 3 times with 500 μL Click-iT reaction wash buffer 2.
Dilute RNA from steps 61 to 100 ng/μL with distilled nuclease free water. Use 10 μL of the diluted RNA (total 1 μg) for “biotinylated nascent RNA:streptavidin magnetic beads” binding reaction.
Prepare RNA:bead binding reaction mix according to Table below and heat the mix at 70°C for 5 min.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_9.csv
Add 50 μL of bead suspension (washed in step 62) into each of heated RNA binding reaction mixes (step 64).
Incubate the microcentrifuge tubes containing the RNA binding reaction mix on a laboratory vertical rotating mixer at room temperature (20°C–22°C) for 30 min to prevent the beads from settling.
Using a magnetic separation rack, wash the beads 5 times with 500 μL Click-iT reaction wash buffer 1 at room temperature.

Wash the beads additional 5 times with 500 μL Click-iT reaction wash buffer 2.
Resuspend the beads in 50 μL of Click-iT reaction wash buffer 2 and proceed immediately to cDNA synthesis using the RNA captured on beads as a template.
Note: At this point, the beads are ready to be used in a cDNA synthesis reaction. Do not store the RNA for future use.
cDNA synthesis of the nascent RNA and qPCR
Timing: 3–4 h
This section describes how to synthesize cDNA from the RNA bound to beads (from step 69) as a template. For the reverse transcription reaction to generate first-strand cDNA, we utilized SuperScript VILO cDNA synthesis kit (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]). This cDNA synthesis kit utilizes random primers for reverse transcription. Below are the brief steps for one RNA sample from brain slice culture. For more RT reactions, scale up the volumes accordingly.
Prepare reverse transcription reaction from the bead-bound RNA. Table below lists the reaction components and their recommended volumes for a 100 μL cDNA synthesis reaction.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1610_10.csv
Heat the RNA-bound bead suspension (step 69) from at 70°C for 5 min.
Immediately add 20 μL of 5× VILO reaction mix into each bead suspension tube and mix it by pipetting up and down.
Bring the reaction mixture to room temperature (20°C–22°C) and gently mix for 5 min on a laboratory vertical rotating mixer.
Add 20 μL of nuclease free water to the reaction mixture.
Add 10 μL of 10× SuperScript Enzyme mix to the reaction mixture. Mix the reaction well by pipetting it up and down.
Incubate the reaction at 46°C for 1 h. Mix gently the reaction tube to prevent the beads from settling during the incubation.

Heat the reaction mixture at 85°C for 5 min to terminate the RT reaction and to release the cDNA from the beads.
Use magnetic separation rack to immobilize the beads and transfer the supernatant containing the cDNA to a new tube.
Note: The RT product can be stored at –80°C until further use.
Proceed to qPCR for BACE1 and GAPDH as described in steps 44–50 at “RT-qPCR analysis of Bace1 mRNA[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.6].” qPCR for ATXN1 can be used as control for ataxin-1 KO and WT samples. To assess any genomic DNA or PCR product contamination, control RT reaction (no RT) that does not contain reverse transcriptase may be included.
